https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

The study of conventional (carbonate and clastic) petroleum systems that contain hydrocarbon accumulations and are defined as those where buoyant forces keep hydrocarbons in place below the sealing caprocks and permit petroleum (oil and/or natural gas) to flow readily from reservoirs into wellbores; i.e. are accessible by standard oilfield techniques and typically do not require advanced drilling, completions, and reservoir stimulation methods. Studies of conventional reservoir include assessment of rock properties, particularly porosity, permeability and compressibility, and of the timing and mechanism of trap formation, as petroleum source rocks, reservoir rocks, impermeable caprocks/seals must form in a favourable sequence to allow accumulation in reservoir rocks (following petroleum generation in source rocks and its ensuing migration therefrom).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Study of the mode of origin and conditions of accumulation of hydrocarbons in the Earth's crust; their exploration, involving application of the techniques of geophysics, geochemistry, paleontology, stratigraphy, and tectonics; and their evaluation. It includes the assessment of petroleum systems and their composite parts: source, migration pathways, reservoir, seal, and method of entrapment.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value:
Definition adapted from:
Allaby, M 2008, A dictionary of Earth sciences, 4th edition: Oxford University Press, doi.10.1093/acref/9780199211944.001.00010.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Study of the mode of origin and conditions of accumulation of hydrocarbons in the Earth's crust; their exploration, involving application of the techniques of geophysics, geochemistry, paleontology, stratigraphy, and tectonics; and their evaluation. It includes the assessment of petroleum systems and their composite parts: source, migration pathways, reservoir, seal, and method of entrapment.

The geological study of unconventional petroleum systems, which comprise formations with tight gas, tight oil, oil sands, oil shale, bitumen, gas shales, coal seam gas/coalbed methane, and gas hydrates, and are defined as those where petroleum is distributed throughout the reservoir at basin-wide scale and in which buoyant forces or the influence of a water column on the location of hydrocarbons in the reservoir are not significant.
